ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Strengthened my Latin skills and learned how to read epistolary format.
Latin grammar fundamentals, epistolographic style in Latin literature.

I developed an incredible understanding of latin Epistolography, a genre I had not pondered much before this course. Moreover, the variety of authors along different genres and the length of readings caused my Latin translation and grammar skills to improve dramatically. I highly enjoyed this course and felt it added a lot to my undergraduate experience
Best hits of Latin letters. Techniques for analysis of Latin texts.

Knowledge of the work of some well-known Latin letter-writers, along with their styles and their historical contexts. I also gained practice translating, grammatically analyzing, and even writing my own Latin prose.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths include exposing students to high amount of Latin. Weakness includes the amount of time spent translating in class without actually getting anywhere. Could be improved with smaller size.
I enjoyed the reading a lot and Prof. Lenski gave very helpful handouts about the background and common grammatical concepts.

I personally do not see any weaknesses to this course. While the variety of authors did make this course more challenging than courses that focus on a single author, this variety caused my Latin skills to improve drastically. Moreover, Professor Lenski provided a lot of support in transition from author to author. The way Professor Lenski broke down incredibly hard grammatical passages was amazing; I have not had a Professor at Yale who has been able to do so as fluidly as he did. Moreover, the weekly scholarly articles were always very interesting and kept the class very engaged in the material. Finally, the exposure of later Latin was a very worthwhile challenge that Professor Lenski did not make too daunting due to his support.

This was a well-organized course with interesting readings and good instruction. There could perhaps have been more analysis of the material beyond just translation and historical context, but overall a great class.
I love the grammar review and the historical context! It is a great course!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. It has made me a stronger Latin student.
Yes, it is a fun class and you learn a lot about famous Roman authors and a diverse set of subjects. Professor Lenski is also a great and knowledgeable professor.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student! Your latin will improve drastically and the material is made so interesting thanks to Professor Lenski.
Yes. Reading Latin letters allows you to get a sense of Roman life in a cool and unique way, and Prof. Lenski is chill and good at explaining the Latin.
Yes! It is a great course to practice Latin and also learn more about Roman History!
